intro: Gnaphalium subacaule, commonly known as the narrow-stemmed cudweed, is a low-growing perennial plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble small daisies. The plant features slender, often hairy stems and small, lance-shaped leaves that are typically arranged alternately along the stem. Its flowering period occurs in late summer to early autumn, producing tiny yellow to white flowers that attract various pollinators. Gnaphalium subacaule is often found in disturbed soils, meadows, and along roadsides, thriving in full sun to partial shade.
